DataElement.preferredName: Subjective Numeracy Scale How Useful Numerical Information Score_6 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A person's stated perception of how often he/she finds numerical information useful, using a six-point likert scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Subjective Numeracy Scale How Useful Numerical Information
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A self-report measure of perceived ability to perform various mathematical tasks and preference for the use of numerical versus prose information. The 8-item scale contains no mathematics questions and has no correct or incorrect answers. Instead, it consists of 4 questions asking respondents to assess their numerical ability in different contexts and 4 questions asking them to state their preferences for the presentation of numerical and probabilistic information. (Fagerlin, et al., Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680)_A survey question about how useful a person finds numerical information.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A self-report measure of perceived ability to perform various mathematical tasks and preference for the use of numerical versus prose information. The 8-item scale contains no mathematics questions and has no correct or incorrect answers. Instead, it consists of 4 questions asking respondents to assess their numerical ability in different contexts and 4 questions asking them to state their preferences for the presentation of numerical and probabilistic information. (Fagerlin, et al., Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680)

Concepts.definition: A self-report measure of perceived ability to perform various mathematical tasks and preference for the use of numerical versus prose information. The 8-item scale contains no mathematics questions and has no correct or incorrect answers. Instead, it consists of 4 questions asking respondents to assess their numerical ability in different contexts and 4 questions asking them to state their preferences for the presentation of numerical and probabilistic information. (Fagerlin, et al., Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680)

Property.preferredDefinition: A survey question about how useful a person finds numerical information.

Concepts.definition: A question about how useful an individual finds or found numerical information.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Numeric code to represent how often something happened using a six-point Likert scale.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Very Often Never Six Range Likert Score 2

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Very Often Never Six Range Likert Score 2
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On most occasions, or in most situations.:Not ever; at no time in the past (or future).:A natural number greater than 5 and less than 7 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of five and one.:The difference between the lowest and highest numerical values; the limits or scale of variation.:A subjective score of 2 on a Likert scale.

Concepts.definition: On most occasions, or in most situations.
Not ever; at no time in the past (or future).
A natural number greater than 5 and less than 7 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of five and one.
The difference between the lowest and highest numerical values; the limits or scale of variation.
A subjective score of 2 on a Likert scale.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Modified long name/definition to meet quality criteria and released as part of caDSR cleanup. mc 7/2/12

ReferenceDocuments.name: How often do you find numeric
ReferenceDocuments.description: How often do you find numerical information to be useful?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Author Names
ReferenceDocuments.description: Fagerlin A, Zikmund-Fisher BJ, Ubel PA, Jankovic A, Derry HA, Smith DM

ReferenceDocuments.name: Measure Citation
ReferenceDocuments.description: Measuring numeracy without a math test: Development of the Subjective Numeracy Scale (SNS). Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Scoring Instructions
ReferenceDocuments.description: All questions scored as marked (1-6) except Question 7 which is reverse coded (6-1). SNS: Average rating across all 8 questions (w/ Q7 reverse coded) SNS ability subscale: Average rating on Questions 1-4 SNS preference subscale: Average rating on Questions 5-8 (w/ Q7 reverse coded)

DataElement.changeDescription: Modified long name/definition and added question text to meet quality criteria and released as part of caDSR cleanup. mc 7/2/12
